urn:contentItem:6055-HGS1-F03R-N34R-00000-00DOJ, Hawley Propose Rules to Hold Big Tech Accountable for 'Censorship'2020-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:31ZLexisNexisDOJ, Hawley Propose Rules to Hold Big Tech Accountable for 'Censorship'Alexander Hall

Jun 17, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) Power players on the Hill and at the Department of Justice are mobilizing and rolling out unprecedented legislation and regulations to hold Big Tech accountable for its censorship of conservatives.The Justice Department is set to crack down today on the Section 230 protections, which have been used by Big Tech companies as a shield from lawsuits. This is being done 'in an effort to make tech companies more responsible in how they police their content,' The Wall Street Journal[1] reported.The Journal made note that 'the department will propose to strike from federal law a provision that allows platforms to delete content that they merely deem to be 'objectionable.'' That is in direct response to abuses by Big Tech firms restricting conservative political content.Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) has also proposed legislation that would reportedly empower users 'who believe the provider is not 'operating in good faith' by consistently and fairly applying its content rules' to sue Big Tech companies for $5,000 and attorneys' fees, according to Axios[2].The Journal reported that these upcoming changes will have a massive impact on Big Tech on multiple fronts:'The department's proposed changes, to be unveiled as soon as Wednesday, are designed to spur online platforms to be more aggressive in addressing illicit and harmful conduct on their sites, and to be fairer and more consistent in their decisions to take down content they find objectionable, the official said.'These actions come after President Donald Trump just last month announced an executive order[3] in response to him being censored by Twitter.

The Journal summarized that 'The executive order sought to impose limits on legal immunity for social-media companies when they are deemed to unfairly curb users' speech, for instance by deleting their posts or suspending their accounts.'The changes being proposed by the Justice Department, however, look to be on an even greater scale. The Journal explained that the legislative changes to be proposed are 'seeking to strip civil immunity afforded to tech companies in a range of other circumstances, the administration official said.' The Journal summarized that Big Tech companies, which have been shielded by Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996 thus far, are in for a reckoning:'Under that law, tech platforms are generally not legally liable for actions of their users, except in relatively narrow circumstances. Internet platforms also are given broad ability to police their sites as they see fit under the current law.'Sen. Hawley will reportedly 'introduce legislation that would give consumers grounds to sue companies like Facebook or Twitter over accusations of selective censorship of political speech' on Wednesday, according to Axios[4].'The Limiting Section 230 Immunity to Good Samaritans Act[5]' reportedly will hold Big Tech accountable to America's fundamental value of free speech. Axios summarized a statement from Hawley's office, suggesting it would 'prevent major online companies from receiving the protections of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act unless they revise their terms of service to include pledges to operate in good faith and details of their content moderation policies.'Hawley explained in a tweet[6] that this bill has both significant legal implications and support from several other Republican senators:'Today I'm introducing new legislation to combat #BigTech censorship. It gives users the right to sue if the big platforms enforce their terms unfairly or unequally. Proud to be joined by ⁦@marcorubio @SenTomCotton @SenatorBraun.' [ 1]: https://www.wsj .com/articles/justice-department-to-propose-limiting-internet-firms-protections-11592391602?mod=e2tw [ 2]:   https://www.axios.com/hawley-unveils-bill-targeting-big-techs-shield-b225c52b-35e2-4392-b11a-afda6357e35f.html?utm_campaign=organic&utm_medium=socialshare&utm_source=twitter [ 3]:   https://www.newsbusters.org/blogs/techwatch/alexander-hall/2020/05/28/trump-expected-launch-executive-order-big-tech-censorship [ 4]:   https://www.axios.com/hawley-unveils-bill-targeting-big-techs-shield-b225c52b-35e2-4392-b11a-afda6357e35f.html?utm_campaign=organic&utm_medium=socialshare&utm_source=twitter [ 5]:   https://www.hawley.senate.gov/sites/default/files/2020-06/Limiting-Section-230-Immunity-to-Good-Samaritans-Act.pdf [ 6]:   https://twitter.com/HawleyMO/status/1273225246334738432

urn:contentItem:5Y33-X711-F03R-N449-00000-00DOJ Hires Antitrust Staff As #8216;Broad Investigation#8217; Into Big Tech Firms Accelerates2020-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:31ZLexisNexisDOJ Hires Antitrust Staff As #8216;Broad Investigation#8217; Into Big Tech Firms AcceleratesZero Hedge

Jan 28, 2020( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1] View original post here[2]. The US Department of Justice Antitrust Division has been on a hiring spree amid investigations into Silicon Valley tech giants, according to Reuters[3], citing two DOJ officials with knowledge of the matter. The department is scheduled to post an advertisement for positions, potentially on Monday, for additional attorneys, paralegals with an interest in tech and others to work in San Francisco to focus on the tech industry, one of the sources said. A job posting for five people for two-year Washington positions that dates from November specifies that the attorneys hired will work on a broad investigation of major digital technology firms into whether they engage in anticompetitive practices.

The posting includes a link to the agency's press release announcing the probes. -Reuters[4] Companies such as Amazon, Facebook and Google are facing a litany of antitrust probes by the US government, along with Congressional investigators and state attorneys general. "We have capacity to take on a good number of folks," said the source, who added that the number of new hires in the antitrust division will depend on the caliber of applicants. The division works in conjunction with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to analyze mergers to ensure they are legal, as well as accusations of price-fixing. In July, the Wall Street Journal reported that the DOJ was opening a broad antitrust review[5] into whether dominant technology firms are unlawfully stifling competition. The review is reportedly centered around examining the practices of online platforms that dominate internet search, social media and retail services; the report notes that the new antitrust inquiry is "the strongest signal yet of Attorney General William Barr's deep interest in the tech sector, and it could ratchet up the already considerable regulatory pressures facing the top U.S. tech firms." The agency is also reportedly looking into how the most dominant tech firms have grown in size and might—and expanded their reach into additional businesses, as well as weather big tech firms have abused the power that comes with having such large networks of users. The DOJ's Antitrust Division began 2019 with a staff of approximately 622, which dropped to around 600 over the course of last year due to a hiring freeze which has recently been lifted. In the past six months, 86 employees have been hired #8212; including an unspecified number of attorneys, paralegals and others. SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Yes. He spent the day with the president. So he's going to fill us in on that, Laura. Thank you very much.

All right. Let's get you caught up now on three breaking stories tonight. The inspector general at the justice department is starting an investigation into what Republicans contend is bias at the DOJ and FBI and the Russia collision investigation and those FISA warrants. We're also learning this evening that President Trump has fired his Veteran Affairs secretary, Dr. David Shulkin. Senior North and South Korean officials are just launching high-level talks to set up a planned summit in April with President Trump.

Team coverage tonight, Lucas Tomlinson standing by at the Pentagon with why Dr. Shulkin was let's go. And who's replacing him. Leland Vittert tracking the diplomatic moves on the Korean Peninsula. But we begin tonight with chief national correspondent, Ed Henry following the new pressure on the FBI. Good evening, Ed.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, great to see you. Democrats initially laughed off these allegations about FISA abuse but there may be some people in the Obama inner circle tonight that are starting to sweat, not to mention former top FBI officials who were supposed to be nonpolitical, like James Comey and Andrew McCabe, who will now be facing even more scrutiny from the justice department inspector general, Michael Horowitz.

Remember, Attorney General Jeff Sessions weeks ago said he wanted Horowitz to handle this and got more heat from supporters of President Trump who said, well, the inspector general is going to bury this. Sessions had passed the buck once again. But this, tonight, is a sign maybe Horowitz moving full speed ahead on what Republican Devin Nunes first brought to the nation's attention with that Republican memo laying out how top FBI and justice department officials in the Obama administration got a warrant in 2016 from the secretive FISA court to spy on former Trump advisor Carter Page. Most importantly, Comey, McCabe and other top officials used information from former British spy, Christopher Steele's anti-Trump dossier to get that warrant without disclosing to the judge that in fact the DNC and Hillary Clinton's campaign had paid for that dirt.

Horowitz declaring in a statement tonight, "As part of this examination, the office of inspector general will review information that was known to the DOJ and FBI at the time the applications were filed from or about an alleged FBI confidential source, that being Steele. Additionally, the inspector general will review the DOJ and FBI relationship, communications with the alleged source as they relate to FISA applications. If circumstances warrant, the inspector general will consider, including other issues that may arise during the course of the review."

That suggest its wide open could go into a whole bunch of issues. And in fact, House intelligence committee chair, Devin Nunes tonight was on with "HANNITY" when he called out Democrats.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R), CALIFORNIA: Well, now, this is effectively boomeranged on them. You have at least, I think half of the American people now know that the other party, the Democrats, appear like they weaponized to some degree, the intelligence services.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: House judiciary chairman Bob Goodlatte is another republican probing the FISA abuse. He has issued a subpoena for more documents on the FBI's handling of the Hillary Clinton e-mail probe. Well, Democrat Jerry Nadler is declaring that that's a problem. "It seems that the subpoena is intended to speed up that production of documents to pivot the discussion back to Hillary Clinton and divert attention from the chaos surrounding the Trump administration and allegations involving the Trump campaign." Well, there were new allegations today in The New York Times that former Trump personal attorney, John Dowd discussed the possibility of pardons with lawyers for Paul Manafort and retired general, Michael Flynn. Ty Cobb, another attorney for the president inside the White House, put out a statement saying, I have only been asked about pardons by the press and have routinely responded on the record that no pardons are under discussion or even under consideration at the White House.

Either way the president's power to pardon is broad. Discussions would not necessarily be improper. The question tonight is whether it becomes part of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe into potential obstruction of justice. Shannon.

BREAM: Ed Henry with the very latest. Thank you so much. We're going to talk about it with the panel, coming up.

In the meantime, President Trump making big news at the White House tonight as his doctor and navy admiral was nominated to take over at the V.A. The two have worked in close proximity at the White House, effectively firing now Secretary David Shulkin. Lucas Tomlinson has the story for us tonight. Lucas.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LUCAS TOMLINSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: For the second time in two weeks, President Trump fired a member of his cabinet, this time acting V.A. secretary Dr. David Shulkin, an Obama holdover, after calls for his removal over an epic scandal boiled over. Last month, the VA watchdogs said Shulkin improperly accepted Wimbledon tickets and his former chief of staff doctored e-mails to justify his wife traveling to Europe with him at tax bear expense.

The inspector general is currently investigating whether his security deal detail was made to deliver furniture from Home Depot to Shulkin's home. President Trump has nominated White House Dr. Ronny Jackson to replace the Shulkin, a navy rear admiral, a surprise choice to lead the government's second largest department. He has served as White House physician over the past three administrations. Recently, Jackson has been criticized by some after giving a glowing report on the president's health.

RONNY JACKSON, NOMINATED AS THE SECRETARY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS: Some people have just great genes. I told the president that if he had a healthier dot over the last 20 years, he might have could love to be 200 years old.

SANJAY GUPTA, CNN CHIEF MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: The president has heart disease. Those numbers qualify him for having heart disease. It clearly needs a plan to and prevent some sort of heart problem down the road.

TOMLINSON: In a statement, President Trump said Admiral Jackson is highly trained and qualified. One of the first GOP lawmakers to call for Shulkin's ouster applauded the move. Dr. Shulkin came from within the V.A. and did nothing to clean up the culture of bureaucratic incompetence that has defined the leadership at the V.A. I'm absolutely convinced that only someone from outside the V.A. can clean up the V.A.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

The president named Robert Wilkie, the Pentagon's undersecretary of defense for personal and readiness, to serve as the acting V.A. secretary until Admiral Jackson is confirmed. But expect Senate Democrats to put up a fight. Shannon?

BREAM: All right. Lucas Tomlinson from the Pentagon. Thank you.

Kim Jong-un's secretive meeting with Chinese President, Xi Jinping, has left many in the U.S. wondering what will happen next. And what it could mean for a future meeting with President Trump.

Leland Vittert joins us live with more on that. Hey, Leland.

LELAND VITTERT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Shannon. Lots of news but very few answers to the core questions here. When and where does the Trump-Kim summit take place, what are the ground rules, and what does the North Koreans really want for their nukes? One thing is sure. The Chinese made it clear with this visit that they play front and center role when it comes to dealing with the Kim regime. The president paid respect to his Chinese counterpart to that effect today tweeting, "Received a message last night from Xi Jinping of China that his meeting with Kim Jong- un went very well and that Kim looks forward to his meeting with me. In the meantime, and unfortunately, maximum sanctions and pressure must be maintained at all cost."

Despite their freeze on missile and nuclear test, the North Koreans appear to be moving forward at all costs and it breakneck speed with their nuclear program. New photo show another reactor, the north claims it's for peaceful electricity generation. But intelligence reports it is also capable of throwing off highly and rich plutonium for more bombs. If the White House or U.S. intelligence community knew about the Chinese summit, they didn't say anything, nor did they seem particularly surprised. The Chinese official state media reiterated the offer by Kim Jong-un of a face- to-face with President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Certainly, we're going to be cautiously optimistic, but we feel like things are moving in the right direction, and that the meeting yesterday was a good indication that the maximum pressure campaign has been working. You saw him leave for the first time since becoming the leader of North Korea, leaving his country for the first time for that meeting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VITTERT: Speaking of leaving, Kim Jong-un used his private luxury train to make the journey to Beijing, a flight that normally takes two hours, evidently Kim doesn't like to fly and showed off the train, as you can see to the Chinese media. So we were turned to when and where a meeting could take place, if the president is going to show up. It's highly unlikely it will be a surprise and if Kim will only travel by a train that moves at a reported 40 miles an hour, fair to say, Shannon, it greatly limits the options for locations.

BREAM: To one continent. It looks like. All right. Leland, thank you very much.

Kim's surprise summit with Chinese president Xi Jinping this week was the first time he traveled outside of his country since he assumed power in 2011. That's according to his own state media. But Beijing is just the start. Next, is a meeting just south of the DMZ with South Korean president Moon Jae-in. Then potentially with President Trump and as yet undisclosed location. He's also rumored to be considering a sit down with Russia's Vladimir Putin, while one of its staunchest critics, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe says he's ready for a meeting too. So, what is drawing him out of Hermit Kingdom all of a sudden?

Let's talk about it with Republican senator from South Carolina, Lindsey Graham, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Great to have you with us, Senator.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: That is a stunning overview. If you told me a year ago that the North Korean leader would be meeting with President Trump, potentially the Russians and the Japanese, I wouldn't believe it, and hats off to President Trump and his team for making this a reality. Maximum pressure has worked.

BREAM: Let's talk first about China, because I read an account today that said for six years, he's been pushing China to have an official meeting with him. I launched a Twitter campaign after getting the request from Emilio's uncle whom I've met on a plane weeks ago. Thanks to your tens of thousands of retweets, and the kindness of many strangers in three short days, videos personalized for Emilio poured in from multiple Avengers and other superheroes. Today one of them was set to call him at the hospital, but the 11-year-old cancer fighter did not make it. Emilio's family started a foundation to help others facing the same struggles that they have. Emilio also wrote a book last year, and all the proceeds will help fund the foundation.

If you want to help, just go to genesfoundation -- that's G-E-N-E-S foundation.com. And please remember this. Emilio proved that social media can be actually an enormous force for good and that there is plenty of kindness in the world. Strangers will often care and have compassion even when it will benefit them in no way. We've seen that over and over since Sunday. So thanks all of you who made that happen. Tonight, most-watched, most trusted, and most grateful you spent the evening with us. Good night from Washington. I'm Shannon Bream.

END

urn:contentItem:5S06-3MK1-DXH2-63R8-00000-00DOJ IG To Investigate Alleged FISA Abuses; Trump Fires VA Secretary, Ronny Jackson To Be Nominated; China Takes Center Stage After Kim Jong Un Visit; Future Of U.S.-North Korea Relations Unclear; Poland Signs $4.75 Billion Deal For U.S. Patriot Missile System Facing Russia; Pro-Life Group Plans Own Walkout Following Gun Protests; Chicago Violence Spikes After New Stop & Frisk Rules2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:31ZLexisNexisFOX NEWS @ NIGHT11:00 PM ESTLindsey Graham, Ethan Bearman, Alayna TreeneNEWSDomestic032801cb.259DOJ IG To Investigate Alleged FISA Abuses; Trump Fires VA Secretary, Ronny Jackson To Be Nominated; China Takes Center Stage After Kim Jong Un Visit; Future Of U.S.-North Korea Relations Unclear; Poland Signs $4.75 Billion Deal For U.S. Patriot Missile System Facing Russia; Pro-Life Group Plans Own Walkout Following Gun Protests; Chicago Violence Spikes After New Stop & Frisk RulesShannon Bream, Ed Henry, Lucas Tomlinson, Leland Vittert, Lisa Boothe, Mollie Hemingway, Trace Gallagher, Michael Tobin, Steve Hilton

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Yes. He spent the day with the president. So he's going to fill us in on that, Laura. Thank you very much.

All right. Let's get you caught up now on three breaking stories tonight. The inspector general at the justice department is starting an investigation into what Republicans contend is bias at the DOJ and FBI and the Russia collision investigation and those FISA warrants. We're also learning this evening that President Trump has fired his Veteran Affairs secretary, Dr. David Shulkin. Senior North and South Korean officials are just launching high-level talks to set up a planned summit in April with President Trump.

Team coverage tonight, Lucas Tomlinson standing by at the Pentagon with why Dr. Shulkin was let's go. And who's replacing him. Leland Vittert tracking the diplomatic moves on the Korean Peninsula. But we begin tonight with chief national correspondent, Ed Henry following the new pressure on the FBI. Good evening, Ed.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, great to see you. Democrats initially laughed off these allegations about FISA abuse but there may be some people in the Obama inner circle tonight that are starting to sweat, not to mention former top FBI officials who were supposed to be nonpolitical, like James Comey and Andrew McCabe, who will now be facing even more scrutiny from the justice department inspector general, Michael Horowitz.

Remember, Attorney General Jeff Sessions weeks ago said he wanted Horowitz to handle this and got more heat from supporters of President Trump who said, well, the inspector general is going to bury this. Sessions had passed the buck once again. But this, tonight, is a sign maybe Horowitz moving full speed ahead on what Republican Devin Nunes first brought to the nation's attention with that Republican memo laying out how top FBI and justice department officials in the Obama administration got a warrant in 2016 from the secretive FISA court to spy on former Trump advisor Carter Page. Most importantly, Comey, McCabe and other top officials used information from former British spy, Christopher Steele's anti-Trump dossier to get that warrant without disclosing to the judge that in fact the DNC and Hillary Clinton's campaign had paid for that dirt.

Horowitz declaring in a statement tonight, "As part of this examination, the office of inspector general will review information that was known to the DOJ and FBI at the time the applications were filed from or about an alleged FBI confidential source, that being Steele. Additionally, the inspector general will review the DOJ and FBI relationship, communications with the alleged source as they relate to FISA applications. If circumstances warrant, the inspector general will consider, including other issues that may arise during the course of the review."

That suggest its wide open could go into a whole bunch of issues. And in fact, House intelligence committee chair, Devin Nunes tonight was on with "HANNITY" when he called out Democrats.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R), CALIFORNIA: Well, now, this is effectively boomeranged on them. You have at least, I think half of the American people now know that the other party, the Democrats, appear like they weaponized to some degree, the intelligence services.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: House judiciary chairman Bob Goodlatte is another republican probing the FISA abuse. He has issued a subpoena for more documents on the FBI's handling of the Hillary Clinton e-mail probe. Well, Democrat Jerry Nadler is declaring that that's a problem. "It seems that the subpoena is intended to speed up that production of documents to pivot the discussion back to Hillary Clinton and divert attention from the chaos surrounding the Trump administration and allegations involving the Trump campaign." Well, there were new allegations today in The New York Times that former Trump personal attorney, John Dowd discussed the possibility of pardons with lawyers for Paul Manafort and retired general, Michael Flynn. Ty Cobb, another attorney for the president inside the White House, put out a statement saying, I have only been asked about pardons by the press and have routinely responded on the record that no pardons are under discussion or even under consideration at the White House.

Either way the president's power to pardon is broad. Discussions would not necessarily be improper. The question tonight is whether it becomes part of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe into potential obstruction of justice. Shannon.

BREAM: Ed Henry with the very latest. Thank you so much. We're going to talk about it with the panel, coming up.

In the meantime, President Trump making big news at the White House tonight as his doctor and navy admiral was nominated to take over at the V.A. The two have worked in close proximity at the White House, effectively firing now Secretary David Shulkin. Lucas Tomlinson has the story for us tonight. Lucas.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LUCAS TOMLINSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: For the second time in two weeks, President Trump fired a member of his cabinet, this time acting V.A. secretary Dr. David Shulkin, an Obama holdover, after calls for his removal over an epic scandal boiled over. Last month, the VA watchdogs said Shulkin improperly accepted Wimbledon tickets and his former chief of staff doctored e-mails to justify his wife traveling to Europe with him at tax bear expense.

The inspector general is currently investigating whether his security deal detail was made to deliver furniture from Home Depot to Shulkin's home. President Trump has nominated White House Dr. Ronny Jackson to replace the Shulkin, a navy rear admiral, a surprise choice to lead the government's second largest department. He has served as White House physician over the past three administrations. Recently, Jackson has been criticized by some after giving a glowing report on the president's health.

RONNY JACKSON, NOMINATED AS THE SECRETARY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS: Some people have just great genes. I told the president that if he had a healthier dot over the last 20 years, he might have could love to be 200 years old.

SANJAY GUPTA, CNN CHIEF MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: The president has heart disease. Those numbers qualify him for having heart disease. It clearly needs a plan to and prevent some sort of heart problem down the road.

TOMLINSON: In a statement, President Trump said Admiral Jackson is highly trained and qualified. One of the first GOP lawmakers to call for Shulkin's ouster applauded the move. Dr. Shulkin came from within the V.A. and did nothing to clean up the culture of bureaucratic incompetence that has defined the leadership at the V.A. I'm absolutely convinced that only someone from outside the V.A. can clean up the V.A.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

The president named Robert Wilkie, the Pentagon's undersecretary of defense for personal and readiness, to serve as the acting V.A. secretary until Admiral Jackson is confirmed. But expect Senate Democrats to put up a fight. Shannon?

BREAM: All right. Lucas Tomlinson from the Pentagon. Thank you.

Kim Jong-un's secretive meeting with Chinese President, Xi Jinping, has left many in the U.S. wondering what will happen next. And what it could mean for a future meeting with President Trump.

Leland Vittert joins us live with more on that. Hey, Leland.

LELAND VITTERT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Shannon. Lots of news but very few answers to the core questions here. When and where does the Trump-Kim summit take place, what are the ground rules, and what does the North Koreans really want for their nukes? One thing is sure. The Chinese made it clear with this visit that they play front and center role when it comes to dealing with the Kim regime. The president paid respect to his Chinese counterpart to that effect today tweeting, "Received a message last night from Xi Jinping of China that his meeting with Kim Jong- un went very well and that Kim looks forward to his meeting with me. In the meantime, and unfortunately, maximum sanctions and pressure must be maintained at all cost."

Despite their freeze on missile and nuclear test, the North Koreans appear to be moving forward at all costs and it breakneck speed with their nuclear program. New photo show another reactor, the north claims it's for peaceful electricity generation. But intelligence reports it is also capable of throwing off highly and rich plutonium for more bombs. If the White House or U.S. intelligence community knew about the Chinese summit, they didn't say anything, nor did they seem particularly surprised. The Chinese official state media reiterated the offer by Kim Jong-un of a face- to-face with President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Certainly, we're going to be cautiously optimistic, but we feel like things are moving in the right direction, and that the meeting yesterday was a good indication that the maximum pressure campaign has been working. You saw him leave for the first time since becoming the leader of North Korea, leaving his country for the first time for that meeting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VITTERT: Speaking of leaving, Kim Jong-un used his private luxury train to make the journey to Beijing, a flight that normally takes two hours, evidently Kim doesn't like to fly and showed off the train, as you can see to the Chinese media. So we were turned to when and where a meeting could take place, if the president is going to show up. It's highly unlikely it will be a surprise and if Kim will only travel by a train that moves at a reported 40 miles an hour, fair to say, Shannon, it greatly limits the options for locations.

BREAM: To one continent. It looks like. All right. Leland, thank you very much.

Kim's surprise summit with Chinese president Xi Jinping this week was the first time he traveled outside of his country since he assumed power in 2011. That's according to his own state media. But Beijing is just the start. Next, is a meeting just south of the DMZ with South Korean president Moon Jae-in. Then potentially with President Trump and as yet undisclosed location. He's also rumored to be considering a sit down with Russia's Vladimir Putin, while one of its staunchest critics, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe says he's ready for a meeting too. So, what is drawing him out of Hermit Kingdom all of a sudden?

Let's talk about it with Republican senator from South Carolina, Lindsey Graham, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Great to have you with us, Senator.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: That is a stunning overview. If you told me a year ago that the North Korean leader would be meeting with President Trump, potentially the Russians and the Japanese, I wouldn't believe it, and hats off to President Trump and his team for making this a reality. Maximum pressure has worked.

BREAM: Let's talk first about China, because I read an account today that said for six years, he's been pushing China to have an official meeting with him. They weren't really interested, it never happened, they held him at arm's length. As soon as it's becoming apparent that he's going to meet with President Trump, China says, hey, come for a visit. They obviously have different interests in the region than we do. There are some similar but there are some differences.

Yun Sun writing a piece in 38 North, says that "Beijing is concerned with any concessions that North Korea might make toward the U.S. in exchange for U.S. security guarantee or settlement that could lead to the unification of the Korean Peninsula by absorption and the emergence of a unified Korea as an American military ally on China's border."

GRAHAM: I think that's a pretty good analysis of what they fear. Now, here's what they hope. They hope that North Korea will stop being a pain in the rear for them. The North Korean nuclear program destabilizes the entire world. I hope that Kim Jong-un was told by the Chinese president, we stand with America. You need to give up your nukes. I would tell the Chinese, our goal is not to reunify South Korea and North Korea. Our goal is to make sure that North Korea gives up their nuclear weapons to protect the American homeland and the world at large. Help us there.

BREAM: Do you think it will though? Because the messages were relayed after their meetings that they're open to denuclearizing the peninsula, there are plenty of skeptics who aren't buying that or wonder what kind of agreement we can get with North Korea as far as rigorous, legitimate inspection.

GRAHAM: Well, one, we've seen this movie before. In 1994, they gave up their nuclear program for food. They took the food and they kept their nukes. The one thing I would tell China and North Korea, the worst mistake you could make is meet with President Trump personally, have a discussion about what to do, and try to play him. If that happens, that's the end of North Korea.

I met with the president today. He doesn't want a war. He's hopeful that this can resolve in ending the North Korea and nuclear threat, stabilizing that part of the world. And I think he's ready to go big. The Korean War is still -- it's never been ended.

BREAM: Technically.

GRAHAM: What I would like to see happen is a peace treaty between South Korea and North Korea, China, and the United States. North Korea give up their weapons. Japan doesn't have them. South Korea doesn't have them. We'll give them an insurance that we're not going to invade North Korea. We're going to tell the Chinese we're not trying to unify the Korean Peninsula, but we are insisting that Kim Jong-un give up his nuclear program. There is a chance for a deal. This is the last, best chance to avoid a war. The worst thing that can happen is North Korea try to play Donald Trump.

BREAM: Well, you have said that the damage from a war with North Korea would be worth it in terms of long-term stability and national security. That scares a lot of people when you say that.

GRAHAM: Well, I don't want to minimize the damage would be great. Worth it. It's all about bad choices. If there's a war between North Korea and us, South Korea and Japan will get hit, hit hard. Thousands of people could die. That is not lost upon me. But if we allow them to get an ICBM, they can hit America with a nuclear tipped missile. The names of Americans are at risk and he will sell anything he develops. He sold to Syria, he tried to help Iraq. So North Korea proliferates nuclear materials. So you got two bad choices. To me, it is worth it to stop him from getting a big nuclear arsenal because he'll give it or sell it to people who would use it if he would not.

BREAM: Let's talk about Russia. Interesting because the president took these steps obviously in tandem with a number of European allies to expel a number of Russian personnel, intelligence officers, those kinds of things and response to this poisoning on British soil that Russians are now saying the U.K. did made it look like the Russians did it. I'm no security expert or professional on so I won't comment on that.

Anyway, a couple of people now stepping up in the mainstream media to praise the president, David Sanger from The New York Times saying this, "It's getting harder to make the argument that the president has not gotten tough with Putin." John Avlon of the Daily Beast saying, "This is big and it deserves credit."

GRAHAM: He deserves a lot of credit, 60 diplomats/spies. The president mentioned that today. The best thing can happen is to unite the world against Russia's aggression, not just be the United States versus Russia, but the entire world. Look what happened when we decided to expel Russian diplomats and spies, the entire world followed President Trump. The best thing he can do in my view, here at home and abroad, is to tell Putin, I don't want to be your enemy but you're making me be your enemy and if you continue to disrupt the world, invade your neighbor, assassinate people, in foreign countries, then you're going to pay a price.

If China -- excuse me, if France and Germany would get behind Trump's efforts to change business practices in China, guess what, China would stop cheating if they had to pay a price. Putin would stop disrupting the world if he paid a price. And I can tell you this. Putin will respond to weakness, to aggression, and he will respond to strength by backing off. And President Trump's got a moment in time here to really make Putin pay a price. His economy is the size of Italy.

BREAM: All right, 15 seconds. You spent 90 minutes with the president today. How did he seem to? Because there's a lot of news swirling around him, much of it not positive.

GRAHAM: Very, very focused, very upbeat. It feels like he's doing a good job. And we have some historic moments coming in may when North Korea and Iran, tax cuts are working, he wants to try to get a deal on immigration that would include the wall. The President was very upbeat and quite frankly, and I think he's done a very good job as Commander-in-Chief.

BREAM: All right. Senator Graham, always good to have you with us. Thanks. Well, the Polish government signing off on a huge deal to buy the U.S. patriot missile defense system today for nearly $5 billion. It's the largest arms procurement deal in Poland's history and it's a major step in modernizing their forces which analysts do not sit well with the Kremlin. Well, the U.S. economy looks to be on stable footing. In the final quarter of 2017, marked the third quarter in a row with GDP close to or exceeding three percent. The pace that the Trump administration set as a target.

Gross domestic product measures the value of every item produced in every service rendered in the U.S. President Trump will visit Northeast Ohio tomorrow afternoon to present his proposed $1.5-trillion program to rebuild some of the country's aging infrastructure. Some economists argue the infrastructure will not add to the U.S. economy. The White House Council of Economic Advisors says the plan would give a significant boost to the GDP over the next ten years adding up to 400,000 new jobs.

Well, they're calling it a boomerang effect. What began as surveillance of a Trump campaign turning into an investigation of the alleged FISA abuse by the FBI under the Obama administration. What it all means for the special counsel probe, next. Plus new developments tonight on a breaking story. A new Trump administration proposal aimed at making sure immigrants don't become dependent on government benefits if they want to attain legal status, lots doesn't like it. Also on tap, from marching for our lives to marching for life. Now another group of students is trying to organize a nationwide school walkout. But will it get some the same kind of support.

BREAM: After being criticized by conservatives for signing a $1.5 trillion spending package last week, well just a small fraction of the border wall funding the White House wanted President Trump is touting its construction on Twitter. The President tweeting photos of portion of the wall being built, adding, great briefing this afternoon on the start of our southern border wall. It comes following are report that the Trump administration is seeking to restrict legal status for immigrants who rely on tax credits and other government welfare programs. Let's talk about with tonight's panel. Radio host Ethan Bearman, Fox News Contributor Lisa Boothe, and The Federalists Mollie Hemingway, also a Fox News Contributor. Good to see all of you tonight.

LISA BOOTHE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Hi, Shannon.

ETHAN BEARMAN, RADIO HOST: Thanks, Shannon.

BREAM: All right. To tell you a little bit more about this. This is what the DHS spokeswoman said. Now, this is their proposal, apparently they say nothing is finalized yet. But once it is approved, it will be released, they will have a comment period the whole nine yards. This is what she said in a statement. The administration is committed to enforcing existing immigration law which is clearly intended to protect the American taxpayer by ensuring that foreign national seeking to enter or remain in the U.S. are self-sufficient. Now, Mollie, the left says, this is an attack on people who have come here illegally and want to gain legal status that -- and it may need some financial help along the way.

MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: This really gets to the heart of the debate about what type of immigration policy you should have. There are some people who think it should be pretty random and lottery based. And then there are people who are pushing for a move to the more Australian or Canadian style where self-sufficiency does play a role. Now, it doesn't play a role for people who have special needs or our refugee status or particular persecution. But in general, a lot of immigration that comes into this country -- a lot of the immigrants that come into this country, American citizens are looking for people who can be self-sufficient and can contribute to the economy. And a lot of immigrants do. But this is one of the tests to make sure that this is working out for current American citizens as well.

BREAM: Well, in reacting to this, the statement from DNC Chair Tom Perez says this, it's another heartless attack on immigrants. Donald Trump should spend less time finding ways to punish hardworking families and more time standing up to the values of inclusion and opportunity that make America great. Your response, Lisa?

BOOTHE: Well, I think Mollie is absolutely right. This is consistent with what we have seen from this White House particularly on legal immigration on the race act as well that President Trump endorse, it was introduced by Senator Cohn and Perdue that looks at what Mollie discussed was a merit- based immigration approach and something that President Trump pushed for as well when he laid out what he would ideally like to see Congress passed and address on the DACA issue. You know, also, so I think this is very consistent with what we have seen from President Trump wanting to bring people into this country that would benefit more economically, maybe not take as much public assistance and, you know, it would bring some sort of skill set to the workforce.

BREAM: Ethan, the DHS says too, this is about making sure that U.S. taxpayers are treated fairly because ultimately there is a price tag for some of these benefits. What say you?

BEARMAN: Well, of course we want U.S. taxpayers to be treated fairly. But the 1996 Welfare Act and Immigration Act of 1996 already addressed this issue. So this is just a very marginal number of people, immigrants -- illegal immigrants already over abundantly contribute to our economy. There are greater number of small business owners that are native-born. They actually work at a higher percentage than native-borns. And they are higher education levels, they actually earn more than native-born Americans. So this is just meat to the base because it is such a tiny percentage of people that we are even talking about. It's not billions of dollars that are being abused or wasted right now.

BREAM: OK. I want to make sure that this next topic I get all three of you in. So if you keep you answers relatively brief. Ethan, I'll start with you and we'll work back. Today the inspector general of the DOJ says he's going to look into these allegations about whether the FISA warrant system was abused, whether the DOJ and FBI under the Obama administration was fair and complied with the law.

BEARMAN: Yes. I think any time that there is an objective investigation by an -- objective investor -- excuse me, inspector general, that's something that we all need. We need to know that the process works. However, in this case it sure seems to be a right-wing move that seems to think of the deep state is so embedded that the FBI is not able to function. Yes. We have a couple of bad apples who were caught red-handed and were removed from the process. But really, I mean, we have the new Manafort connection to the Russian intelligence and that's not what we're talking about.

BREAM: Lisa?

BOOTHE: There are also bad actors that were in part helping to lead these investigations, that's where the concern boils down to. But I do think to Ethan's point, Michael Horowitz is going to be deemed as a more objective investigator in this term. However he doesn't have the prosecutorial authority which is why, you know, people like Chairman Gowdy, also members of the Senate calling for a second special counsel.

BREAM: Uh-hmm. Mollie the top Democrat on this judiciary committee says this is a conspiracy theory that's been debunked, it's a waste of time and money.

HEMMINGWAY: Well, in the last year, you've had Congressional committees on both sides of, you know, the senate and the House looking into Russian meddling, you've had t he inspector general looking into Hillary Clinton e- mail probe. And what everybody has found is some violation of processes and serious problems at the department of Justice and FBI. You've already had at least six, seven, eight people who were fired, demoted, moved around because of these problems. And you have very serious issues with FISA abuse. So these are secret courts, it's incumbent upon our government to make sure that we are -- we are handling the surveillance authority well. And we do need to restore the credibility of our Federal Law Enforcement. This I.G. is a good step, it's a small step though because they can't -- the I.G. can't compel testimony from people who have left FBI or DOJ. And it also doesn't deal with the problems that we found at state, CIA and other agencies as well. So, we'll probably still need a special prosecutor just so everyone can trust the FBI and DOJ.

BREAM: Yes. The calls for those continue. All right. Panel, you were fabulous. We want you to come back. So stick around, we've got some more hot topics for you in just a minute. Thank you, guys. Meanwhile, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is reportedly the richest man in the world but his network took a serious tumble today all because he's reportedly made one very powerful enemy. Plus the news stories are so unbelievable, we have to remind you they are actually legit. The real news roundup coming up.

BREAM: In the wake of anti-gun student walkout, the California teacher was suspended for asking whether pro-life protesters could do the same thing. She wound up suspended, now, one of her students is fighting back. Trace Gallagher, has all the details from the West Coast. Hey, Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Shannon. The nationwide pro- life walkout is specifically meant to imitate the recent gun violence protest except the goal this time is to shine a bright light on the lives destroyed by abortion. The event will also test if there's a double standard when it comes to allowing students to protest things that take lives.

The walkout is being organized by 17 year old, Brandon Gillespie, he is a junior at Rocklin High School outside of Sacramento. Gillespie, says he wants to honor the lives of aborted babies, raise awareness of what he calls the injustices of Planned Parenthood, and to protest the suspension of his history teacher, Julianne Benzel, who was placed on leave when she brought up the double standard. Here is the teacher.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JULIANNE BENZEL, TEACHER, ROCKLIN HIGH SCHOOL, CALIFORNIA: I open up the discussion for -- if schools, not only just our school and our administration but across the country are going to allow one group of students to get up during class --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right.

BENZEL: -- and walkout to protest one issue, --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Right.

BENZEL: -- would they still give the same courtesy to another group of students who wanted to get up and walk out to protest? And I use the example of abortion --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GALLAGHER: Ms. Benzel, who's back teaching now says the upcoming pro-life walkout will literally answer the double standard question. The event is now set for April 11th, and the students are asking for the very same 17 minutes given to students who protested gun violence. It remains unclear how schools across the country will respond.

Meantime, we're getting a better idea of exactly, who participated in the March for Our Lives against gun violence. And it -- apparently, it wasn't mostly young people. A sociology professor at the University of Maryland and her six-person research team randomly surveyed hundreds of people who joined in the march and found 70 percent were women and quoting, "Only about 10 percent of the participants were under 18. The average age of the adults in the crowd was just under 49 years old."

She also says 27 percent of the participants had never protested before and most of the new protesters were not motivated by gun-control but rather, by issues of peace, and of President Trump. Shannon.

BREAM: All right, Trace. Very interesting details, thank you. Well, tonight, the ACLU is urging Greyhound not to let ICE agents search its buses for illegal immigrants without a warrant.

Meanwhile, the ACLU's efforts against law enforcement may have had some perhaps unintended consequences. Researchers are blaming tougher rules on police officers for Chicago's huge spike in homicides. They're calling at the ACLU effect, the ACLU calling it junk science. Senior Correspondent Mike Tobin takes a look at the evidence from Chicago tonight.

MICHAEL TOBIN, FOX NEWS SENIOR CORRESPONDENT: The ACLU is to blame for Chicago's 2016 increase in violent crime, that according to a new study from the University of Utah.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PAUL CASSELL, LAW PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF UTAH: We have a collection of data that come together to make it clear that causation exists here.

TOBIN: The study concludes burdens placed on the city's police force have taken their toll. Street protest erupted in 2015, in response to a video of black teenager Laquan McDonald, being shot 16 times by a Chicago police officer.

In the aftermath, the ACLU in Chicago police reach an agreement to address accusations of racial profiling. Police officers were required to fill out elaborate cards after stop and frisk. Researcher say the form with 70 entries take 15 to 20 minutes to complete. As a result, stops dropped by 82 percent in 2016. Homicides jumped by 58 percent, and Chicago endured an additional 1100 gun crimes.

The study examined other factors, from anger on the street to the opioid epidemic. However, it concluded that the ACLU effect is the anomaly and cops are discouraged from checking suspicious people for weapons.

CASSELL: Criminals on the streets of Chicago became emboldened to carry guns, and deterrent effect decreased. And when there were more guns on the street being carried by criminals, the predictable result is an increase in gun-related crimes.

TOBIN: The spike in bloodshed is undeniable. That and enhanced scrutiny of a police frequently gets attention from the president.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: What the hell is going on in Chicago?

TOBIN: An ACLU lawyer says you can't just look at the chronology and blame the contact cards.

KAREN SHELEY, ATTORNEY, AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION, ILLINOIS: Its junk science, it makes claims that the math that it uses control that one thing caused another.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TOBIN: The ACLU also claims that most of the entries on the contact cards are required by the Chicago P.D., not their organization. And representatives challenge the objectivity of the researchers who also authored a study in 2017, reaching the conclusion that Miranda requirements reduce police effectiveness. Shannon, back to you.

BREAM: Time for a quick "ROUNDUP OF THE REAL NEWS" out there. The way is often derided by the mainstream media for being weak on Russia or even colluding with President Vladimir Putin, to influence the 2016 election, The New York Times is actually crediting President Trump with getting tough on Russia, after expelling 60 Russian diplomats earlier this week. David Sanger is the great lady chief Washington correspondent.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID SANGER, CHIEF WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT, THE NEW YORK TIMES: He is getting a harder to make the argument that the president has not got in tough with Putin. This is certainly a tougher move, for example, than President Obama took when he expelled 30 some odd diplomats after the election issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: President Trump, also getting tough on portraits of government officials. One of three bills signed into law yesterday, the Eliminating Government-funded Oil-painting Act bars the use of taxpayer funds for portraits of federal workers. Like former EPA administrator Lisa Jackson, former Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, and more. Some of these portraits cost taxpayers $40,000 each.

Well, Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania High School has a rifle team with equipment more than 40 years old. That's not the only problem facing the Mountaineers, the school board if they are voted Monday night to reject a $5,000 grant from the National Rifle Association meant to help them buy new gear and guns.

So, the team put together a Go-Fund Me site with an appeal for help that says, "Let's put our political ideology aside and come together as a community in support of our rifle team." Well, tonight, they've nearly doubled their original goal after about a dozen local businesses got together and decided to help fund the team.

Well, classic '90s T.V. show made its much-anticipated return last night, but, is Roseanne really representing Trump voters? Tonight's panel returns for what is sure to be a lively debate.

BREAM: It's a scene that's all too familiar too many American families that divide over the 2016 election. ABC showed us by reviving "Roseanne" after a 20 year high at us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LAURIE METCALF, AS JACKIE HARRIS IN A SITCOM, ROSEANNE: How could you have voted for him, Roseanne?

ROSEANNE BARR, ACTRESS, COMEDIAN: He talked about jobs, Jackie. He said he'd shake things up. I mean, this might come as a (INAUDIBLE) shock to you but we almost lost our house the way things are going.

METCALF: Have you looked at the news? Because now things are worse.

BARR: Not on the real news.

METCALF: Oh, police!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: "Roseanne's" debut scoring massive ratings in American cities like New York, but also all across the middle of America, dominating in States where President Trump won. Like Ohio, there is a debate about exactly why. So let's talk about it with our panel tonight. I thought it was interesting guys, it had monster ratings but not everybody agreed it was necessarily a good thing for conservatives because Roseanne's character supports Trump.

Ben Shapiro writing this, he said, "There's something else going on in "Roseanne" that should disturb conservatives. The redefinition of Trump supporters as blue-collar leftists rather than conservatives. Roseanne's character is pro-gay marriage, pro-abortion, feminist, and pro- transgenderism. And the implication is that she's a good person because of these views, but the real difference between Trump voters and Hillary voters are economic in nature, not cultural." Lisa, what do you make of that?

BOOTHE: I don't want to get an argument with Ben Shapiro because he's a pretty smart guy there, but I also think that -- look, if you try to look at the Trump coalition, it's sort of a hodgepodge of individuals in this country. So, I think you certainly have people like Roseanne Barr, who's a Trump supporter.

Herself, in real life, also an executive producer of this show that -- you know, maybe a little bit more socially liberal but voted on him for the economic issues alone. But I also think you additionally have people that went for President Trump because of these cultural words. Again, President Trump sort of had this broad, hodgepodge of a coalition. So, I see his point, I think it's a smart point, but I don't necessarily a 100 percent agree with the point he is making.

BREAM: Ethan, what do you make of those monster ratings last night?

BEARMAN: Well, I say congratulations to the show. The cast, I think they did a great job. I'm not necessarily the biggest fan but I'm going to tell you something, Ben Shapiro, is totally wrong on this one. It's about love, it's not about hate, and that's what Roseanne is preaching here and what she's been doing for many, many years.

She led the way both the advocate and out have come out in support of Roseanne, not just the show -- I think, but the show 24 years ago -- almost 24 years ago was a groundbreaker in terms of the first kiss between two women on T.V. So, that's a big deal for a lot of people because especially in light of what the president has been doing with some of the anti-LGBT moves, Roseanne, shows that you can love and support Trump at the same time, well, the LGBT.

BREAM: OK, and I think that's Ben's concern is that it portrays Trump voters is being ones who care about the economy but not these cultural issues. He doesn't think that's the case, but -- you know, we'll see. We love having Ben on, to maybe we can talk about this.

All right, I want to make sure we get to our second topic. We'll start with you, Mollie. A young student out in California says he's going to do a pro-life walkout, April 11th, I believe is the time a date for that. He wants to test a couple of things. He says this, he says, "Along with being a movement commemorating the millions of children who fell victim to abortion, the movement is one that stands for all students' rights to freedom of speech and assembly."

He says, he wants to test this theory about whether it will get the same kind of support that the anti-gun rally has did.

HEMINGWAY: Well, it's interesting that the study came out showing that the people at this weekends' march, the average age was 50, and there weren't that many children there. If you go to the March for Life which is held annually in D.C., and also in state capitals and other cities throughout the country, you are blown away by how many young people are there, high school students and even younger. This is an issue of ending the destruction of human life in the womb and violence in the womb and how that hurts women and their children is an issue that young people care deeply about. And it is something that the media have not done a very good job covering. And I think it's a really interesting question to ask, whether schools will be supportive of this as they were actively colluding and trying to push this anti-gun rights march that they did.

BREAM: Yes, and Ethan, this student directly was a student of the teacher got suspended out in California for asking this and having this conversation in her class. Do you think the two topics will be treated the same? What do you of this plan?

BEARMAN: I mean, I always support people to exercise their First Amendment rights, but there is a significant difference between an already existing march for life and pro -- anti-abortion rally that goes on and a reaction by a lot of people. By the way, I was at the march for our lives with my two small children, well under the age of 50, and my kids are way under the age of 50. So I think we saw a lot of young people there. I don't -- that study was somewhat non-scientific in D.C. only. But the point is this, the kids in Parkland and around the country are worried about the violence that took place at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. Abortions are not happening in high school classrooms so these are different topics and there are separate marches for that.

BREAM: We got to leave it there because we're out of time. But thank you all, Ethan, Lisa and Mollie, we'll watch April 11th and we'll see what happens.

HEMMINGWAY: Thank you, Shannon.

BEARMAN: Thank you.

BREAM: Thank you, guys. All right, Facebook under fire, Amazon stocks plummeting as a third news technology company raises eyebrows with a controversial appointment with board of directors breaking down the tech headlines next.

BREAM: Amazon chair slumping after Axios reported that President Trump believes the e-commerce giant is making life harder for small businesses and is reportedly considering legal means to change that. Joining me now from Los Angeles, Steve Hilton, Host of the "NEXT REVOLUTION" on Sunday nights right here on Fox, also, the Co-Founder and CEO of a tech company himself and Axios Reporter Alayna Treene. Great to have both of you with us tonight.

ALAYNA TREENE, REPORTER, AXIOS: Great to have be here.

BREAM: Steve, there's been a lot of hostility in recent weeks against a lot of the big tech companies. Is it paying to specific stories do you think were there's a broader backlash?

STEVE HILTON, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: It's a broader backlash, Shannon. In many ways, I think it's really helpful that it's happening because it's shining a spotlight on something really important, which is that these tech companies have just got too big and too powerful and it mirrors something that is happening in the economy generally where you got a concentration of power, of economic power and that's always bad news. It's bad news when it happens in government when you get a concentration of power in Washington. That's why I believe in decentralizing power from the federal government to the states and to communities. But the same thing needs happen in the economy too. We actually need to really toughen up the antitrust laws and start breaking up these companies, not just tech, throughout the economy, to get more competition into the marketplace.

BREAM: OK, and Alayna, to that point, the President apparently, the reporting from your outlet, Axios is that he'd to possibly take some steps against Amazon, thinking it's hurting brick-and-mortar stores, retailers, shopping malls, people in real estate, which is a business where he has a lot of friends, the quote is, "the tech behemoth Trump wants to go after is Amazon according to five sources who has discussed it with him. He's obsessed with Amazon, a source said, "obsessed." Alayna?

TREENE: Well, it's definitely interesting to see and that's exactly what the reporting shows. And really, what we're seeing is the President, he is a 1950s man. He's a businessman before he was President. He kind of is nostalgic for the days that it used to be and he's starting to see -- talking to Steve's point, he thinks that there's a lot of power in the hands of these tech companies, and Amazon in particular for its e-commerce aspect of that and what it's doing to mom-and-pop stores and other retailers that he sees it as a big threat to some of those smaller businesses. And so, he's looking at perhaps taking some action. Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said today that there is nothing in the works right now but from what the sources have told Axios is that he really is looking at anti -- maybe anti-trust regulations or some other tax treatment that they might be abusing.

BREAM: And another tech company that's revolutionized the way we get entertainment, Netflix has announced Susan Rice, former Ambassador and former NSA under the Obama Administration is going to join their board. I want to get a quick reaction for both of you. Steve, first to you.

HILTON: I think you know, there's nothing that -- not to be upset about except the fact that it is so typical, isn't it? People who serve in government and then they basically cash in on their public service and they get who burned up by these big companies and stock on their board. It's happened forever, it's part of the swamp. That is the real story here rather than the politics of Netflix. It's all about the swamp. This is how they work.

BREAM: And Alayna, you know, there's been backlash and threats of a boycott because of the Ambassador's role in the Benghazi fiasco. How do you think that plays out?

TREENE: Well, a lot of people have been taking on to Twitter and other forms of social media to say that they're going to boycott Netflix for putting Susan Rice on the board. And we saw similar things happen when there was buzz that Barack Obama and Michelle Obama might also have a Netflix series on Netflix. And so a lot of people believed, just like Steve's point, as he was saying it's the swamp coming to these big media outlets and a lot of people don't like that crossover from the political world in Washington into some of the more tech companies and media companies that they see as their entertainment and ways of escaping all of that.

BREAM: Well, a tough day for many in the tech companies. A tough week in the markets. We'll see how they fare tomorrow with the next news cycle. Steve and Alayna, great to have both of you with us tonight. Thanks.

TREENE: Thank you.

HILTON: Thanks, Shannon. See you soon.

BREAM: OK, so many of you who have reached out in the last few days after I put out a Twitter plea for a young boy he was very ill and had one last wish. So we've got an update for you right after the break.

BREAM: I want to close tonight by updating you about young Emilio who is dying wish was to get a message of one of the Avengers. I launched a Twitter campaign after getting the request from Emilio's uncle whom I've met on a plane weeks ago. Thanks to your tens of thousands of retweets, and the kindness of many strangers in three short days, videos personalized for Emilio poured in from multiple Avengers and other superheroes. Today one of them was set to call him at the hospital, but the 11-year-old cancer fighter did not make it. Emilio's family started a foundation to help others facing the same struggles that they have. Emilio also wrote a book last year, and all the proceeds will help fund the foundation.

If you want to help, just go to genesfoundation -- that's G-E-N-E-S foundation.com. And please remember this. Emilio proved that social media can be actually an enormous force for good and that there is plenty of kindness in the world. Strangers will often care and have compassion even when it will benefit them in no way. We've seen that over and over since Sunday. So thanks all of you who made that happen. Tonight, most-watched, most trusted, and most grateful you spent the evening with us. Good night from Washington. I'm Shannon Bream.

urn:contentItem:5S0C-8PG1-JBHT-D504-00000-00DOJ IG To Investigate Alleged FISA Abuses; Trump Fires VA Secretary, Ronny Jackson To Be Nominated; China Takes Center Stage After Kim Jong Un Visit; Future Of U.S.-North Korea Relations Unclear; Poland Signs $4.75 Billion Deal For U.S. Patriot Missile System Facing Russia; Pro-Life Group Plans Own Walkout Following Gun Protests; Chicago Violence Spikes After New Stop & Frisk Rules2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:31ZLexisNexisDOJ IG To Investigate Alleged FISA Abuses; Trump Fires VA Secretary, Ronny Jackson To Be Nominated; China Takes Center Stage After Kim Jong Un Visit; Future Of U.S.-North Korea Relations Unclear; Poland Signs $4.75 Billion Deal For U.S. Patriot Missile System Facing Russia; Pro-Life Group Plans Own Walkout Following Gun Protests; Chicago Violence Spikes After New Stop & Frisk RulesLanhamFULL TEXT

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Yes. He spent the day with the president. So he's going to fill us in on that, Laura. Thank you very much.

All right. Let's get you caught up now on three breaking stories tonight. The inspector general at the justice department is starting an investigation into what Republicans contend is bias at the DOJ and FBI and the Russia collision investigation and those FISA warrants. We're also learning this evening that President Trump has fired his Veteran Affairs secretary, Dr. David Shulkin. Senior North and South Korean officials are just launching high-level talks to set up a planned summit in April with President Trump.

Team coverage tonight, Lucas Tomlinson standing by at the Pentagon with why Dr. Shulkin was let's go. And who's replacing him. Leland Vittert tracking the diplomatic moves on the Korean Peninsula. But we begin tonight with chief national correspondent, Ed Henry following the new pressure on the FBI. Good evening, Ed.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, great to see you. Democrats initially laughed off these allegations about FISA abuse but there may be some people in the Obama inner circle tonight that are starting to sweat, not to mention former top FBI officials who were supposed to be nonpolitical, like James Comey and Andrew McCabe, who will now be facing even more scrutiny from the justice department inspector general, Michael Horowitz.

Remember, Attorney General Jeff Sessions weeks ago said he wanted Horowitz to handle this and got more heat from supporters of President Trump who said, well, the inspector general is going to bury this. Sessions had passed the buck once again. But this, tonight, is a sign maybe Horowitz moving full speed ahead on what Republican Devin Nunes first brought to the nation's attention with that Republican memo laying out how top FBI and justice department officials in the Obama administration got a warrant in 2016 from the secretive FISA court to spy on former Trump advisor Carter Page. Most importantly, Comey, McCabe and other top officials used information from former British spy, Christopher Steele's anti-Trump dossier to get that warrant without disclosing to the judge that in fact the DNC and Hillary Clinton's campaign had paid for that dirt.

Horowitz declaring in a statement tonight, "As part of this examination, the office of inspector general will review information that was known to the DOJ and FBI at the time the applications were filed from or about an alleged FBI confidential source, that being Steele. Additionally, the inspector general will review the DOJ and FBI relationship, communications with the alleged source as they relate to FISA applications. If circumstances warrant, the inspector general will consider, including other issues that may arise during the course of the review."

That suggest its wide open could go into a whole bunch of issues. And in fact, House intelligence committee chair, Devin Nunes tonight was on with "HANNITY" when he called out Democrats.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R), CALIFORNIA: Well, now, this is effectively boomeranged on them. You have at least, I think half of the American people now know that the other party, the Democrats, appear like they weaponized to some degree, the intelligence services.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: House judiciary chairman Bob Goodlatte is another republican probing the FISA abuse. He has issued a subpoena for more documents on the FBI's handling of the Hillary Clinton e-mail probe. Well, Democrat Jerry Nadler is declaring that that's a problem. "It seems that the subpoena is intended to speed up that production of documents to pivot the discussion back to Hillary Clinton and divert attention from the chaos surrounding the Trump administration and allegations involving the Trump campaign." Well, there were new allegations today in The New York Times that former Trump personal attorney, John Dowd discussed the possibility of pardons with lawyers for Paul Manafort and retired general, Michael Flynn. Ty Cobb, another attorney for the president inside the White House, put out a statement saying, I have only been asked about pardons by the press and have routinely responded on the record that no pardons are under discussion or even under consideration at the White House.

Either way the president's power to pardon is broad. Discussions would not necessarily be improper. The question tonight is whether it becomes part of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe into potential obstruction of justice. Shannon.

BREAM: Ed Henry with the very latest. Thank you so much. We're going to talk about it with the panel, coming up.

In the meantime, President Trump making big news at the White House tonight as his doctor and navy admiral was nominated to take over at the V.A. The two have worked in close proximity at the White House, effectively firing now Secretary David Shulkin. Lucas Tomlinson has the story for us tonight. Lucas.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LUCAS TOMLINSON, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: For the second time in two weeks, President Trump fired a member of his cabinet, this time acting V.A. secretary Dr. David Shulkin, an Obama holdover, after calls for his removal over an epic scandal boiled over. Last month, the VA watchdogs said Shulkin improperly accepted Wimbledon tickets and his former chief of staff doctored e-mails to justify his wife traveling to Europe with him at tax bear expense.

The inspector general is currently investigating whether his security deal detail was made to deliver furniture from Home Depot to Shulkin's home. President Trump has nominated White House Dr. Ronny Jackson to replace the Shulkin, a navy rear admiral, a surprise choice to lead the government's second largest department. He has served as White House physician over the past three administrations. Recently, Jackson has been criticized by some after giving a glowing report on the president's health.

RONNY JACKSON, NOMINATED AS THE SECRETARY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS: Some people have just great genes. I told the president that if he had a healthier dot over the last 20 years, he might have could love to be 200 years old.

SANJAY GUPTA, CNN CHIEF MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: The president has heart disease. Those numbers qualify him for having heart disease. It clearly needs a plan to and prevent some sort of heart problem down the road.

TOMLINSON: In a statement, President Trump said Admiral Jackson is highly trained and qualified. One of the first GOP lawmakers to call for Shulkin's ouster applauded the move.
